article.title: Geography_of_Cambodia
article.paragraph: Cambodiais a country inIndochinamainland South-east Asia, borderingThailand,Laos,Vietnam, theGulf of Thailandand covers a total area ofconvert181035km2sqmi0on. The country is situated in its entirety inside theTropical savanna climatetropicalIndomalaya ecozoneIndomalayan ecozonecite webhttp://www.mrd.gov.kh/index.php?optionLand and Resource of CambodiaMinistry of Rural DevelopmentJanuary 26, 2009June 1, 2015and theUTC+07:00Indochina Time zone(ICT).cite web http://www.timeanddate.com/time/zones/ictICT – Indochina Time (Standard Time)Time and Date ASOctober 28, 2015

Cambodia's maingeographygeographicalfeatures are the low lying Central Plain that includes theTonl Sapbasin, the lowerMekong Riverflood-plains and theBassac Riverplain surrounded by mountain ranges to the north, east, in the south-west and south. The central lowlands extend into Vietnam to the south-east. The south and south-west of the country constitute aconvert443kmmi0onlong coast at the Gulf of Thailand, characterized by sizablemangrovemarshes,peninsulas, sandy beaches andheadlands and bays. Cambodia's territorial waters account for over 50 islands. The highest peak isPhnom Aural, sittingconvert1810mft0above sea level.cite webhttp://www.rrcap.ait.asia/lc/cd/html/countryrep/cambodia/report.pdfCambodia Study AreaRegional Resource Centre for Asia and the Pacific(RRC.AP)May 13, 2015cite webhttp://geodata.rrcap.unep.org/all_reports/cambodia_081010.pdfCambodia Environment Outlook - NATURAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES - Geography and ClimateUnited Nations Environment ProgrammeMay 17, 2015cite web https://books.google.com.kh/books?idCambodiaGoogle BooksOctober 31, 2015

The landmass is bisected by theMekong river, which atconvert486kmmi0onis the longest river in Cambodia. After extensive rapids,Khone Fallsturbulent sectionsandcataractsinLaos, the river enters the country atStung Trengprovince, is predominantly calm and navigable during the entire year as it widens considerably in the lowlands. The Mekong's waters disperse into the surrounding wetlands of central Cambodia and strongly affect the seasonal nature of theTonl Saplake.cite webhttp://ffw.mrcmekong.org/south.htmInformation Resources - Southern PartMekong River CommissionMay 11, 2015May 14, 2015cite webhttp://whrm-kamoto.com/assets/files/World%20geographical%20dictionary_CAM%2030%20May2013.pdfWorld Geographical Dictionary On Cambodia six distinct terrestrial eco‐regions in Cambodia have been recognizedWater Hazard and Risk managementMay 31, 2013June 26, 2015

Two third of the country's population live in the lowlands, where the rich sediment deposited during the Mekong's annual flooding makes the agricultural lands highly fertile. AsDeforestation in Cambodiadeforestationand over-exploitation affected Cambodia only in recent decades, forests, low mountain ranges and local eco-regions still retain much of their natural potential and although still home to the largest areas of contiguous and intact forests in mainland Southeast Asia, multiple serious environmental issues persist and accumulate, which are closely related to rapid population growth, uncontrolledglobalizationand inconsequent administration.cite webhttp://www.lizasreef.com/HOPE%20FOR%20THE%20RAIN%20FORESTS/rain_forests_of_the_world.htmRain Forests of the WorldLizas ReefMay 13, 2015cite webhttp://rainforests.mongabay.com/20cambodia.htmEnvironmental issues in CambodiaRainforests MongabayAugust 15, 2014May 13, 2015

The majority of the country lies within theTropical savanna climatezone, as the coastal areas in the South and West receive noticeably more and steady rainMango showersbeforeand during the wet season. These areas constitute the easternmost fringes of theMonsoon of South Asiasouth-west monsoon, determined to be inside theTropical monsoon climate. Countrywide there are two seasons of relatively equal length, defined by varyingprecipitationas temperatures and humidity are generally high and steady throughout the entire year.cite bookhttp://www.tourismcambodia.com/tripplanner/general-travel-information/climate-and-weather.htmClimate and WeatherTourism of CambodiaMay 18, 2015
article.heading: Geological development
article.paragraph: Southeast Asia consists ofallochthonouscontinental blocks fromGondwanaland. These include the South China,Indochina,Titiwangsa MountainsSibumasu, and West Burma blocks, which amalgamated to form the Southeast Asian continent during thePaleozoicandMesozoicperiods.cite webhttps://books.google.com.kh/books?idLate Palaeozoic and Mesozoic Ecosystems in SE Asia Google BooksMay 13, 2015

The current geological structure of South China and South-East Asia is determined to be the response to the "Indo-sinian" collision in South-East Asia during theCarboniferous.cite webhttps://hal.inria.fr/file/index/docid/202662/filename/Shu-ComptesRendusGeosciences.pdfLate Palaeozoic–Early Mesozoic geological features of South China: Response to the Indosinian collision events in Southeast Asia Inria FranceMay 13, 2015The Indo-Sinianorogenywas followed by extension of the Indo-Chinese block, the formation ofriftbasins andthermal subsidenceduring the earlyTriassic.cite bookhttp://books.google.com.kh/books?idThe Geology of ThailandGoogle BooksMay 13, 2015cite webhttp://web.missouri.edu/~lium/pdfs/Papers/Yang2013_tibet.pdfThe Indo-Asian continental collision: A 3-D viscous modelUniversity of MissouriMay 13, 2015cite webhttp://jubilotheque.upmc.fr/ead.html?idNote sur la géologie du Cambodge et du Bas-LaosJubilothèqueMay 13, 2015

The Indochinacontinentalblock, which is separated from the South China Block by the Jinshajiang-AilaoshanSuture (geology)Suturezone, is an amalgamation of the Viet-Lao, Khorat-Kontum, Uttaradit (UTD), and Chiang Mai-West Kachinterranes, all of which are separated bySuture (geology)suture zonesor ductileshear zones.The Khorat-Kontum terrane, which includes western Laos, Cambodia and southern Vietnam, consists of the KontumMetamorphic core complexmetamorphic complex,Paleozoicshallow marine deposits, upperPermianarc volcanic rocks andMesozoicTerrigenous sedimentterrigenoussedimentaryrocks.cite webhttp://www.cugb.edu.cn/upload/20600/papers_upload/news_2010122105227.pdfStructural and geochronological constraints on the tectonic evolution of the Dulong-Song Chay tectonic dome in Yunnan province, SW ChinaChina University of GeosciencesMay 13, 2015

The central plains consist mainly ofQuaternarysands,loamandclay, as most of the northern mountain regions and the coastal region are largely composed ofCretaceousgranite,Triassicstones andJurassicsandstoneformations.cite webhttps://www.behance.net/gallery/4295309/Russian-Geological-Map-of-CambodiaGeological Map of Cambodia, 1991, 1:500,000BehanceJune 21, 2012May 13, 2015cite webhttp://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/2003GC000619/pdfQuantitative bedrock geology of east and Southeast AsiaWiley Online LibraryJanuary 17, 2004May 13, 2015

article.paragraph: Bowl-shaped,cite webhttp://www.cambodiavolunteer.info/general-info.phpVolunteer and Adventures in Cambodia - Gerneral InfoVolunteer and Adventures in CambodiaMay 14, 2015Cambodia coversconvert181035km2sqmi0onin the south-western part of theIndochinaIndochinese peninsulaas its landmass and marine territory is situated entirely within thetropics.

The bowl's bottom represents Cambodia's interior, about 75 percent, consisting ofAlluvial plainalluvialflood-plains of theTonl Sapbasin, the lowerMekongRiver and theBassac Riverplain, whose waters feed the large and almost centrally located wetlands. As humans preferably settle in these fertile and easily accessible central lowlands, major transformations and widespread cultivation throughPaddy fieldwet-rice agriculturehave over the centuries shaped the landscape into distinctive regionalArable landcultivated lands.cite webhttp://books.irri.org/9712201007_content.pdfRice in the Cambodian economy, past and present - Khmer farmers have been growing rain fed rice for at least 2,000 yr, possibly longer in the case of upland rice. Historians believe that rice - growing technologies may have been imported...Cambodia - IRRI - Australia ProjectJuly 3, 2015cite webhttps://books.google.com.kh/books?idThe Killing of Cambodia: Geography, Genocide and the Unmaking of Space James A. Tyner - Chapter 1Google BooksJune 6, 2015Domestic plants, such asBorassus flabellifersugar palms,Coconuttrees andbananagroves almost exclusively skirt extensive rice paddies, as natural vegetation is confined to elevated lands and near waterways.cite webhttp://www.microworld.org/en/news-from-the-field/article/rice-farming-cambodia-beginners-guideRice farming in Cambodia: A beginner's guideMicroWorldJuly 11, 2011May 14, 2015TheMekongtraverses the north to south-east portions of the country, where the low-lying plains extend intoVietnamand reach theSouth China Seaat theMekong Deltaregion.

Cambodia'sMittelgebirgelow mountain ranges- representing the walls of the bowl - remain as the result of only rather recent substantial infrastructural development and economic exploitation - in particular in remote areas - formidably forested.cite webhttps://books.google.com.kh/books?idTerrestrial Ecoregions of the Indo-Pacific: A Conservation AssessmentGoogle BooksMay 27, 2015The country is fringed to the north by theDangrek Mountainsplateau, bordering Thailand and Laos, to the north-east by theAnnamite Range, in the south-west by theCardamom Mountainsand in the South by theDmrei MountainsElephant Mountains. Highlands to the north-east and to the east merge into theCentral VietnamCentral Highlandsand theMekong Deltalowlands of Vietnam.cite webhttp://www.angkortempleguides.com/cambodia-geography.htmlCambodia GeographyAngkor Temple GuidesJune 6, 2015cite webhttp://countrystudies.us/cambodia/36.htmCambodia - TopographyU.S. Library of CongressJune 7, 2015

A heavily indented coastline at theGulf of Thailandofconvert443kmmi0onlength and 60 offshore islands, that dot the territorial waters and locally merge with tidal mangrove marshes - the environmental basis for a remarkable range of marine and coastal eco-regions.cite webhttp://www.nationsencyclopedia.com/geography/Afghanistan-to-Comoros/Cambodia.htmlCambodia - Location and size, Territories and dependencies, Climate, Topographic regions, Oceans and seasEncyclopedia of the NationsMay 27, 2015
article.heading: Soils
article.paragraph: Image:Acrisolprof.JPGthumb120px'''low fertileAcrisol'''"Sandy materials cover a large proportion of the landscape of Cambodia, on account of theSiliceous rocksiliceoussedimentaryformations that underlie much of the Kingdom.Mesozoicsandstonedominates most of the basement geology in Cambodia and hence has a dominating influence on the properties of upland soils.Arenosols(sandy soils featuring very weak or no soil development) are mapped on only 1.6% of the land area."

"Sandy surface textures are more prevalent than the deep sandy soils that fit the definition forArenosols. Sandy textured profiles are common amongst the most prevalent soil groups, includingAcrisolsandLeptosols. TheAcrisolsare the most prevalent soil group occupying the lowlands - nearly half of the land area of Cambodia. Low fertility and toxic amounts of aluminium pose limitations to its agricultural use, crops that can be successfully cultivated includerubber tree,oil palm,coffeeandsugar cane.cite webhttp://www.fao.org/docrep/W8594E/w8594e00.htm#World reference base for soil resourcesFOOD AND AGRICULTURE ORGANIZATION OF THE UNITED NATIONS Rome, 1998June 7, 2015The main subgroups are: Gleyic Acrisols (20.5%, Haplic Acrisols (13.3%), Plinthic Acrisol (8.7%) and Ferric Acrisol (6.3%)."cite webhttp://www.fao.org/docrep/010/ag125e/AG125E07.htmManagement of tropical sandy soils for sustainable agricultureFAO Document RepositoryMay 14, 2015

article.heading: Regions
Central plain
article.paragraph: The vastAlluvial plainalluvialandLacustrine plainlacustrineinterconnected Cambodian flood-plain is a geologically relatively recent depression where the sediments of the Mekong and its tributaries accumulate as waters are subject to frequent course changes.cite webhttp://www.mrcmekong.org/RAK/html/1.2.5a_lower_reaches.htmlTHE LOWER REACHES AND DELTA REGIONSMRC MekongMay 14, 2015The area coversconvert25069km2sqmi0on. TheTonl Saplake and - river system occupies the lowest area. The Tonle Sap river is a waterway that branches off the Mekong near Phnom Penh in the north-westerly direction and meets the Tonle Sap lake after aroundconvert115kmmi0on. Its waters' flow reverses direction every year, caused by greatly varying amounts of water carried by the Mekong over the course of a year and the impact of monsoonal rains, that coincides with the river's maximum.cite webhttp://encyclopedia2.thefreedictionary.com/Cambodian+PlainCambodian Plain definition of Cambodian PlainFree Online EncyclopediaJune 6, 2015

The plains of the Mekong and Tonle Sap basin are confined in the North by the Dangrek and Central Annamite Mountains, and to the South by the Cardamom Mountains and Elephant Mountains. The plains completely surround the Tonle Sap Lake in the western half of the country and wind their way through the middle of the country following the course of the Mekong River. The two basins actually form a single body of water, the whole of which effects about 75% of Cambodias land cover.cite webhttp://www.treeseedfa.org/doc/GeneEcologicalZonation/4DescriptionofEcological.pdfDescription of Ecological Factors in CambodiaCambodia Tree Seed ProjectMay 20, 2015
article.heading: Flow reversal
article.paragraph: File:Tonle Sap Lake phases.gifthumbright'''Tonle Sap Lake volume over the course of one year'''The Mekong river and its tributaries increase water volumes in spring (May) on the northern hemisphere, mainly caused by melting snows. As the Mekong enters Cambodia (over 95% of its waters have already joined the river) it widens and inundates large areas.

paragraph.template: quotation<arg name=""There is extreme hydrodynamic complexity in both time and space and it becomes impossible to measure channel discharge. Water levels, not flow rates and volumes, determine the movement of water across the landscape."{{cite web |url">http://www.mekonginfo.org/assets/midocs/0001968-inland-waters-overview-of-the-hydrology-of-the-mekong-basin.pdf |title

article.paragraph: The plain's deepest point - the Tonle Sap - flooded area varies from a low of aroundconvert2700km2mi2onwith a depth of around 1 meter at the end of the dry season (April) toconvert26000km2mi2onand a depth of up to 9 meters in October/November. This figure rose toconvert45000km2mi2onduring 2000 when some of the worst flood conditions recorded caused over 800 deaths in Cambodia and Vietnam.

Inflow starts in May/June with maximum rates of flow of around 10,000 m3/s by late August and ends in October/November, amplified by precipitation of the annual monsoon. In November the lake reaches its maximum size. The annual monsoon coincides to cease around this time of the year. As the Mekong river begins its minimum around this time of the year and its water level falls deeper than the inundated Tonle Sap lake, Tonle Sap river and surrounding wetlands, waters of the lake's basin now drains via the Tonle Sap river into the Mekong. As a result the Tonle Sap River (length around 115 km/71 mi) flows 6 months a year South-East (Mekong) to North-West (lake) and 6 month a year in the opposite direction. The mean annual reverse flow volume in the Tonle Sap isconvert30km3mi3on, or about half of the maximum lake volume. A further 10% is estimated to enter the system by overland flow from the Mekong.cite webhttp://tonlesap.net/Tonle Sap Cambodia - River LakeTonle SapMay 12, 2015cite webhttp://www.wepa-db.net/policies/state/cambodia/overview1_4.htmState of water : CambodiaWEPAMay 12, 2015The Mekong branches off intoBassac Riverseveral armsnearPhnom Penhand reaches Vietnamese territory south of Koh Thom and Loek Daek districts ofKandal Province.
article.heading: Southern Mountains
article.paragraph: File:Tatai River, Cambodia.jpgthumb'''Tatai River, draining the southern slopes of theCardamom Mountains'''File:Kampot Cambodia.jpgthumb'''Kampot Province, countryside with remoteDmrei MountainsElephant Mountains'''This region represents the eastern parts of the original extent of the wet evergreen forests that cover the Cardamom - and Elephant Mountains in South-West Cambodia and along the mountains east of Bangkok in Thailand.cite webhttp://www.worldwildlife.org/ecoregions/im0106Southeastern Asia: Southern Cambodia stretching into Thailand and VietnamWWFMay 12, 2015

The densely wooded hills receive rainfall of 150200 inches (3,8005,000 mm) annually on their western slopes (which are subject to theMonsoon of South AsiaSouth-West monsoons) but only 4060 inches (1,0201,520 mm) on their eastern - rain shadow - slopes.cite webhttp://www.globalspecies.org/ecoregions/display/IM0106Cardamom Mountains rain forestsGlobal SpeciesMay 12, 2015

OccupyingKoh Kong ProvinceandKampong Speu Province, running in a north-western to south-eastern direction and rising to more than 1,500 meters. The highest mountain of Cambodia,Phnom Aural, at 1,810 meters is located inAoral DistrictinKampong Speu Province.The Cardamom Mountains form - including the north-western part of Chanthaburi Province, Thailand, the 'Soi Dao Mountains' -the Cardamom Mountains Moist Forests Ecoregion, that is considered to be one of the most species-rich and intact natural habitats in the region. The climate, size inaccessibility and seclusion of the mountains have allowed a rich variety of wildlife to thrive. The Cardamom and Elephant Mountains remain to be fully researched and documented.cite webhttp://wwf.panda.org/about_our_earth/ecoregions/cardamom_moist_forests.cfmCardamom Mountains Moist ForestsWWF PandaMay 12, 2015cite webhttp://www.cardamom.org/region.htmlCardamom Mountain RegionCardamom OrgMay 12, 2015cite webhttp://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/saving-cambodias-cardamom-mountains-one-frog-timeSaving Cambodia's Cardamom Mountains, one frog at a timePhnom Penh PostSeptember 15, 2008May 12, 2015cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/earth/hi/earth_news/newsid_8584000/8584979.stmNew cryptic gecko species is discovered in CambodiaBBCMarch 24, 2010May 20, 2015

Chur Phnum Dmrei - A north-south-trending range of high hills, an extension of the Cardamom/Krvanh Mountains, in south-eastern Cambodia, rising to elevations of between 500 and 1,000 meters. Extending 70 miles (110 km) north from the Gulf of Thailand, they reach a high point in the Bok Ko ridge at Mount Bokor (3,547 feet [1,081 m]) near the sea.cite webhttp://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/150627/Damrei-MountainsDâmrei Mountains CambodiaEncyclopedia BritannicaMay 12, 2015cite webhttps://books.google.com.kh/books?idWorld and Its Peoples: Cambodia, Laos, and VietnamGoogle BooksMay 12, 2015cite webhttp://lod.openlinksw.com/describe/?uriAbout: Dâmrei MountainsOpenLink VirtuosoDecember 5, 2013May 20, 2015cite webhttp://kh.geoview.info/chuor_phnum_damrei,1831359Chuŏr Phnum DâmreiGeo-ViewMay 20, 2015
To the south-west of the Southern mountain ranges extends a narrow coastal plain that contains the Kampong Saom Bay area and the Sihanoukville peninsula, facing theGulf of Thailand.
article.heading: Northern Mountains
article.paragraph: A forested range of hills averaging 1,5002,000 feet (450600 m), dividing Thailand from Cambodia, mainly formed of massive sandstone with slate and silt. A few characteristic basalt hills are located on the northern side of the mountain chain. This eastwest-trending range extends from the Mekong River westward for approximately 200 miles (320 km), merging with the highland area near San Kamphaeng, Thailand. Essentially the southern escarpment of the sandstoneKhorat Plateauof northeastern Thailand, the Dngrk range slopes gradually northward to the Mun River in Thailand but falls more abruptly in the south to the Cambodian plain. Its highest point is 2,497 feet (761 m). The watershed along the escarpment in general terms marks the boundary betweenThailandand Cambodia, however there are exceptions. The region is covered in dryevergreen forest, mixeddipterocarp forest, anddeciduousdipterocarp forests. Tree species likePterocarpus macrocarpus,Shorea siamensisandXylia xylocarpaXylia xylocarpa var. kerriidominate. Illegal logging are issues on both, the Thai as well as on the Cambodian side, leaving large hill stretches denuded, vulnerable tree species such asDalbergia cochinchinensishave been affected.cite webhttp://www.bangkokpost.com/news/local/277288/dsi-claims-illegal-logging-rampantDSI claims illegal logging rampantBangkok PostJanuary 29, 2012June 7, 2015Forest fires are common during the dry season.cite webhttp://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/150936/Dangrek-MountainsDângrêk MountainsEncyclopedia BritannicaMay 16, 2015

Lying to the east of the Mekong River, the long chain of mountains called the Annamite Mountains of Indochina and the lowlands that surround them make up the Greater Annamites ecoregion. Levels of rainfall vary from 1,500 - 3,850 mm annually. Mean annual temperatures are about 20 C. This eco-region contains some of the last relatively intactTropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forestsmoist forestsin Indochina. Moisture-laden monsoon winds, that blow in from theGulf of Tonkinensure pemanent high air humidity. Plants and animals adapted to moist conditions, to seek refuge here and evolve into highly specialized types that are found nowhere else on Earth.cite webhttp://www.worldwildlife.org/ecoregions/im0152Southeastern Asia: Vietnam into Laos and CambodiaWWFMay 16, 2015cite webhttp://encyclopedia2.thefreedictionary.com/Annamite+CordilleraAnnamite CordilleraThe Free DictionaryMay 16, 2015cite webhttp://wwf.panda.org/about_our_earth/ecoregions/annamite_moist_forests.cfmAnnamite Range Moist ForestsWWFMay 16, 2015

Ethnically diverseMore than 30 ethnic groups of indigenous people live in the Annamites, each with their distinctive and traditional music, language, dress and customs. The natural resources of the Greater Annamites are vital to all of these people.cite webhttp://wwf.panda.org/what_we_do/where_we_work/project/projects_in_depth/greater_annamites_ecoregion/about_the_area/About the Annamites EcoregionWWF PandaMay 16, 2015

The landscape has suffered from rubber farming, logging and particularly mining, although sizable areas of pristine jungle survive, which are home to rare and endemic wildlife.cite webhttp://regionalgeography.org/101blog/?pTHE VANISHING RAINFORESTS (AND CULTURES) OF EASTERN CAMBODIARegional GeogBlogDecember 27, 2012May 16, 2015
article.heading: Coast
article.paragraph: Cambodia's coastal area coversconvert17237km2sqmi0on, distributed among 4 provinces:Sihanoukville province,Kampot province,Koh Kong province, andKep province. The total length of the Cambodian coastal area has been disputed over the years. The generally accepted length is 440 kilometers, a 1997 survey by theDanish International Development AgencyDANIDAorganization set the length atconvert435kmmi0on, and theOil Authorityin 1973 determined the coast to beconvert450kmmi0onlong.cite webhttp://www.czmcam.org/attachments/article/24/2006-09-29%20EE%20lesson%20EN-3.pdfPart III: Main Resources in the Cambodia’s Coastal ZoneCambodia - Coastal Zone ManagementJune 7, 2015TheFood and Agriculture Organizationclaims a length ofconvert557kmmi0onin of its studies.cite webhttp://www.fao.org/docrep/004/ab561e/ab561e05.htmCambodia - some relevant facts - INTRODUCTION - Cambodia has a mainland coastline of 557 km on the Gulf of Thailand.FAO - UNJune 19, 2015

The southern mountain ranges drain to the south and west towards the shallow sea. Sediments on the continental shelf are the basis for extensive mangroves marshes, in particular in theKoh Kong provinceand the Ream National Park.cite webhttp://www.mekong-protected-areas.org/cambodia/docs/cambodia_field.pdfField Study: CambodiaProtected areas and development in the Lower Mekong River regionMay 12, 2015

They include 23 inKoh Kong ProvinceKoh Kong province, 2 inKampot ProvinceKampot province, 22 inSihanoukville ProvinceSihanoukvilleand 13 inKrong Kep (town)Kep city.[sic]"cite webhttp://www.topasia.com.kh/index.php?pageGENERAL INFORMATION OF CAMBODIA - GEOGRAPHY - Coastal AreaTOP ASIA Travel & ToursMay 27, 2015Most islands are, apart from the two small groups of the outer islands, in relative proximity to the coast. article.heading: Climate
article.paragraph: File:Map rainfall Cambodia.jpgthumbleft'''Map of rainfall regimes in Cambodia, source:Danish International Development AgencyDANIDA'''File:Koppen World Map Aw.pngthumbright300pxWorldwide zones of Tropical savanna climate (Aw).Image:Koppen World Map Am.pngthumbright300pxWorldwide zones of tropical monsoon climate (Am).Cambodia's climate, like that of much the rest of mainland Southeast Asia is dominated bymonsoons, which are known as tropical wet and dry because of the distinctly marked seasonal differences. The monsoonal air-flows are caused by annual alternating high pressure and low pressure over the Central Asian landmass. In summer, moisture-laden airthe southwest monsoonis drawn landward from the Indian Ocean. The flow is reversed during the winter, and the northeast monsoon sends back dry air. The southwest monsoon brings the rainy season from mid-May to mid-September or to early October, and the northeast monsoon flow of drier and cooler air lasts from early November to March. Temperatures are fairly uniform throughout theTonl SapBasin area, with only small variations from the average annual mean of aroundconvert25°C1.

The maximum mean is about 30 C ; the minimum mean, about 24 C. Maximum temperatures of higher than 32 C, however, are common and, just before the start of the rainy season, they may rise to more than 38 C. Minimum night temperatures sporadically fall below 20 C.cite webhttp://www.cambodiaweather.net/weather/sihanoukville-cambodia-weather-in-january.htmlSihanoukville weather in JanuaryCambodiaWeather net comMay 27, 2015in January, the coldest month. May is the warmest month - although strongly influenced by the beginning of the wet season, as the area constitutes the easternmost fringe of theMonsoon of South Asiasouth-west monsoon. Tropical cyclones only rarely cause damage in Cambodia.cite webhttp://www.canbypublications.com/cambodia/climate.htmCambodia: Climate and WeatherCanby Publications Co.May 12, 2015cite webhttp://www.visit-mekong.com/cambodia/weather.htmCAMBODIA WEATHER - CLIMATE AND SEASONS IN CAMBODIAVisit MekongMay 12, 2015

The total annual rainfall average is betweenconvert1000and1500mmin1us, and the heaviest amounts fall in the southeast. Rainfall from April to September in theTonl SapBasin-Mekong Lowlands area averagesconvert1300to1500mmin1usannually, but the amount varies considerably from year to year. Rainfall around the basin increases with elevation. It is heaviest in the mountains along the coast in the southwest, which receive fromconvert2500mmin1usto more thanconvert5000mmin1usof precipitation annually as the southwest monsoon reaches the coast. This area of greatest rainfall, however, drains mostly to the sea; only a small quantity goes into the rivers flowing into the basin. Relative humidity is high throughout the entire year; usually exceeding 90 percent. During the dry season daytime humidity rates average around 50 percent or slightly lower, climbing to about 90 percent during the rainy season.cite webhttp://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/90520/Cambodia/52452/ClimateCambodia’s climateEncyclopedia BritannicaMay 14, 2015
article.heading: Hydrology
article.paragraph: File:Mekong floating homes.jpgthumb'''floating homes on the Mekong'''File:Drainage Cambodia.jpgthumb'''overviewDrainage divides'''File:Mekong tributary Cambodia.jpgthumb'''Mekong tributary,Stung Treng Province'''The Mekong River and its tributaries comprise one of the largest river systemsin the world.cite webhttp://whrm-kamoto.com/assets/files/Lower%20Mekong%20Basin%20Existing%20environment%20and%20development%20needs.pdfLower Mekong Basin Existing environment and development needsWater Hazard and Risk managementJune 26, 2015The central Tonle Sap - Great Lake has several input rivers, the most important being the Tonle Sap river during the rainy season, which contributes 62 percent of the total water supply. The other rivers in the sub-basin and direct rainfall on the lake contribute the remaining 38 percent. Other major rivers are the Sen river, Sreng river, Pursat (Pouthisat) river,Sisophon RiverSisophon river,Mongkol Borei RiverMongkul Borey river, andSangkae RiverSangker river.cite bookhttp://www.fao.org/nr/water/espim/country/cambodia/print1.stmFAO's Information System on Water and AgricultureAQUASTATMay 16, 2015cite bookhttp://www.wepa-db.net/policies/state/cambodia/river.htmState of water environmental issuesWater Environment Partnership in AsiaMay 16, 2015

Except for the smaller rivers in the southeast, most of the major rivers and river systems in Cambodia drain into the Tonle Sap or into the Mekong River. The Cardamom Mountains and Elephant Range form a separate drainage divide. To the east the rivers flow into the Tonle Sap, as in the south-west rivers flow into the Gulf of Thailand. Toward the southern slopes of the Elephant Mountains, small rivers flow south-eastward on the eastern side of the divide.

The Mekong River flows southward from the Cambodia-Laos border to a point belowKrati (town)Kratie city, where it turns west for about 50 kilometers and then turns southwest to Phnom Penh. Extensive rapids run aboveKrati (town)Kratie city. FromKampong Cham Provincethe gradient slopes very gently, and inundation of areas along the river occurs at flood stageJune through Novemberthrough breaks in the natural levees that have built up along its course. At Phnom Penh four major water courses meet at a point called the Chattomukh (Four Faces). The Mekong River flows in from the northeast and the Tonle Sap, a river emanating from the Tonle Sapflows in from the northwest. They divide into two parallel channels, the Mekong River proper and theBassac River, and flow independently through the delta areas of Cambodia and Vietnam to the South China Sea.

The flow of water into the Tonle Sap is seasonal. In spring, the flow of the Mekong River, fed by monsoon rains, increases to a point where its outlets through the delta cannot handle the enormous volume of water. At this point, the water pushes northward up the Tonle Sap river and empties into the Tonle Sap lake, thereby increasing the size of the lake from about 2,590 square kilometers to about 24,605 square kilometers at the height of the flooding. After the Mekong's waters crest when its downstream channels can handle the volume of water the flow reverses, and water flows out of the engorged lake.

As the level of the Tonle Sap retreats, it deposits a new layer of sediment. The annual flooding, combined with poor drainage immediately around the lake, transforms the surrounding area into marshlands, unusable for agricultural purposes during the dry season. The sediment deposited into the lake during the Mekong's flood stage appears to be greater than the quantity carried away later by the Tonle Sap River. Gradual silting of the lake would seem to be occurring; during low-water level, it is only about 1.5 meters deep, while at flood stage it is between 10 and 15 meters deep.cite webhttp://www.mekonginfo.org/assets/midocs/0001968-inland-waters-overview-of-the-hydrology-of-the-mekong-basin.pdfOverview of the Hydrology of the Mekong BasinMekong River CommissionJune 6, 2015cite webhttp://countrystudies.us/cambodia/38.htmCambodia - RiversU.S. Library of CongressJune 7, 2015

article.paragraph: File:Forest and land cover Cambodia.jpgthumbleft'''map of forests, vegetation and land use in Cambodia'''Cambodia has one of the highest levels of forest cover in the region as the interdependence of Cambodias geography and hydrology makes it rich in natural resources and biological diversity - among the bio-richest countries in Southeast Asia. The Royal Government of Cambodia estimates Cambodia contains approximately 10.36 million hectares of forest cover, representing approximately 57.07% of Cambodias land area (2011).cite bookhttp://cambodia.panda.org/where_we_work/dry_forests/Saving Cambodia's Dry ForestsWWFMay 16, 2015On the contrary, international observers and independent sources provide rather different numbers. Consensus permeates, as most sources agree, thatDeforestation in Cambodiadeforestation, loss of seasonal wetlands and habitat destruction - among countless minor factors - correlates with the absence of strict administrative control and indifference in law enforcement - not only in Cambodia but the entire region.cite bookhttp://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/may/02/greater-mekong-forest-coverGreater Mekong countries 'lost one-third of forest cover in 40 years'The GuardianMay 16, 2015cite newshttp://www.nytimes.com/1999/01/15/news/15iht-mekong.t.htmlEcology:Cambodia's Next Man-Made DisasterThe New York Times CompanyJanuary 15, 1999May 20, 2015cite webhttp://news.mongabay.com/2013/0318-cambodia-wetlands.htmlCambodia loses half its seasonal wetlands in 10 yearsMongabayMarch 18, 2013May 26, 2015

Figures and assessments are numerous as are available sources. as seen in numbers below, which provide a wide range for interpretation. About 69,000 ha (1%) of forest cover is planted forest. Overall Cambodias forests contain an estimated 464 million metric tonnes of carbon stock in living forest biomass.cite bookhttp://theredddesk.org/countries/cambodia/statisticsStatistics for CambodiaThe REDD DeskDecember 1, 2012May 16, 2015Approximately 40% of Cambodias Forests have some level of protection, while one of theMinistry of Planning (Cambodia)Cambodia Millennium Development Goalstargets is to achieve a 60% forest cover by 2015.cite webhttp://www.mop.gov.kh/Home/CMDGs/tabid/156/Default.aspxThe Cambodian Millennium Development Goals (CMDGs)Ministry Of PlanningMay 26, 2015cite webhttp://www.kh.undp.org/content/cambodia/en/home/mdgoverview.htmlThe Millennium Development Goals - Eight Goals for 2015United Nations Development ProgrammeMay 26, 2015

article.heading: Southern Annamites Montane Rain Forests ecoregion
article.paragraph: TheAnnamite RangeSouthern Annamites Montane Rain Forests ecoregionof theMontane ecologymontaneforests of Kontuey Nea, "the dragon's tail" in the remote north-west of Cambodia, where the boundaries of Cambodia, Laos, and Vietnam meet, is remarkably rich inbiodiversity. The relatively intact forests occupy a broad topographic range - from lowlands with wet evergreen forests to montane habitats with evergreen hardwood andconiferforests. The complex geological, topographic and climatic ( rainfall and temperature ) facets that characterize the region make forest structure and composition unique and very variable. There is a unusually high number of near-endemic andendemicspecies among the many species to be found in the area,. The entire eco-region has a size ofconvert94000km2sqmi0on.cite bookhttp://www.eoearth.org/view/article/156174/Southern Annamites montane rain forestseoearthMay 7, 2014May 18, 2015cite webhttps://php.radford.edu/~swoodwar/biomes/?page_idTropical Rainforest - Biomes of the WorldDepartment of Geospatial Science Radford UniversityJune 7, 2015cite webhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/shared/spl/hi/pop_ups/07/sci_nat_vietnam_unveiled/html/1.stmIn pictures: Vietnam unveiled, Green flashBBC NewsJune 7, 2015
article.heading: The Great Lake ecosystem
article.paragraph: Image:Engkabang (Shorea sp.) (15607560356).jpgthumbright'''Dipterocarpaceae'''The Tonle Sap, also known as the Great Lake in central Cambodia is the largest freshwater lake in Southeast Asia and one of the richest inland fishing grounds in the world. The Lake functions as a natural flood water reservoir for the Mekong system as a whole and therefore is an important source of water for the Mekong Delta during the dry season.cite webhttp://whrm-kamoto.com/assets/files/PublicationFile20%20tonele%20sap.pdfThe importance of Tonle Sap at multiple levelsWater Hazard and Risk managementJune 26, 2015The ecosystem has developed as a result of the Mekongs seasonal flow fluctuations. A belt of freshwater mangroves known as the "flooded forest" surrounds the lake. The floodplains in turn are surrounded by low hills, covered with evergreen ordeciduousTropical and subtropical dry broadleaf forestsdry forestwith prevalentDipterocarpaceaedipterocarpvegetation. The eco-region consists of a mosaic of habitats for a great number of species.cite webhttp://193.62.154.38/diptero/Dipterocarpaceae Data BaseForestry Research ProgrammeMay 26, 2015The forest gradually yields to bushes and finally grassland with increasing distance from the lake.
Henri Mouhot: "Travels in the Central Parts of Indo-China" 1864

paragraph.template: quotation<arg name=""During more than five months of the year, the great lake of Cambodia, Touli-Sap, covers an immense space of ground: after that period there is a diminution in depth owing to the great evaporation, but its width remains nearly unaltered. Although its waters increase in volume during the rainy season, these are not swelled by the streams from the mountains on its western boundary, but by the strength of the current from the Mekon which pours into it its overflow.[sic]"{{cite web |url">http://www.gutenberg.org/files/46559/46559-h/46559-h.htm |title

article.paragraph: On higher quality soils or at higher elevation, areas of mixed deciduous forest and semi-evergreen forestscite webhttp://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1O7-semievergrenssnltrpclfrst.htmlsemi-evergreen seasonal tropical forestEncyclopedia comMay 26, 2015occur. This variety of vegetation types accounts for the quantity and diversity of species of the Great Lake ecosystem. Interlocking forest, - grassland and marshland patches provide the many facets and refugiae for the abundant local wildlife.cite bookhttp://www.mrcmekong.org/mekong-basin/hydrology/HydrologyMekong River CommissionMay 18, 2015cite webhttp://cambodia.panda.org/where_we_work/dry_forests/dry_forest_ecology/Dry Forest EcologyWorld Wide Fund For NatureMay 20, 2015

The lakes flooded forest and the surrounding floodplains are of utmost importance for Cambodia's agriculture as the region represents the cultural heart of Cambodia, the center of the national freshwater fishery industry - the nation's primary protein source.cite bookhttp://www.fao.org/docrep/005/y4586e/y4586e04.htmBiodiversity and the Ecosystem Approach in Agriculture, Forestry and FisheriesFood and Agriculture Organization of the United NationsMay 18, 2015Threats to the lake include widespread pollution, stress through growth of the local population which is dependent on the lake for subsistence and livelihood, over-harvesting of fish and other aquatic - often endangered - species, habitat destruction and potential changes in the hydrology, such as the construction and operation of dams, that disrupt the lake's natural flood cycle. However, concerns that the lake is rapidly filling with sediment seem - according to studiescite webhttp://water.tkk.fi/English/wr/research/global/material/ambio_37(3)/ambio_2008_kummu&al.pdfSediment: Curse or Blessing for Tonle Sap LakeAalto UniversityJune 6, 2015- to be unfounded at the present time.cite webhttp://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00027-006-0855-0#page-1Species diversity and ecology of Tonle Sap Great Lake, CambodiaSpringer International Publishing AGJanuary 17, 2006May 20, 2015
article.heading: Wetlands
article.paragraph: Image:Coastal plains near Sihanoukville.jpgthumbright'''coastal wetlands near Ream,Sihanoukville Province'''Wetlands cover more than 30 per cent of Cambodia. In addition to the Mekong River and the Tonle Sap floodplain there are the Stung Sen River and the coastal Stung Koh Pao - and Stung Kep estuaries ofKoh Kong ProvinceandKep Province. The freshwater wetlands of Cambodia represent one of the most diverse ecosystems worldwide.cite webhttp://www.mekonginfo.org/assets/midocs/0002811-inland-waters-review-of-wetland-and-aquatic-ecosystem-in-the-lower-mekong-river-basin-of-cambodia.pdfReview of Wetland and Aquatic Ecosystem in the Lower Mekong River Basin of CambodiaMekong Info - Mekong River CommissionAugust 1, 2003May 26, 2015The areas extensive wetland habitats are the product of the annual Mekong maximum, the simultaneous wet season and the drainage paths of a number of minor rivers. See also:Geography of Cambodia#HydrologyThe numerous and varied wetlands are Cambodia's central and traditional settlement area, the productive environments for rice cultivation, freshwater fisheries, other forms of agriculture and aquaculture and the constantly growing tourism sector.cite bookhttp://www.mrcmekong.org/mekong-basin/natural-resourcesNatural ResourcesMekong River CommissionMay 18, 2015Considering the eco-region's importance, a variety of plans for local wetland management consolidation existcite webhttp://www.iucn.org/news_homepage/news_by_date/2011_news_gb/july_2011/?7890/Streamlining-wetland-conservation-in-CambodiaStreamlining wetland conservation in CambodiaIUCN, International Union for Conservation of NatureJuly 15, 2011May 26, 2015cite webhttp://www.wwt.org.uk/conservation/saving-wetlands-and-wildlife/temp/cambodian-lower-mekong-wetlands/Cambodian Lower Mekong Wetlands - Project overviewWildfowl & Wetlands Trust (WWT) - Wetland CentreMay 26, 2015with varying degrees of completion.cite webhttp://www.crdt.org.kh/programs/tab/Projects We Have CompletedCambodian Rural Development TeamMay 26, 2015
article.heading: Coastal habitats
article.paragraph: The Cambodian coastline consists of 60,000 ha of some 30 species ofmangroves- among the most biologically diverse wetlands on earth.cite webhttp://www.idrc.ca/EN/Resources/Publications/Pages/ArticleDetails.aspx?PublicationIDProtecting mangrove forests in CambodiaInternational Development Research Centre (IDRC)May 26, 2015The most pristine mangrove forests are found in Koh Kong Province. In addition to mangroves, sea-grass beds extend throughout the coastal areas, especially in Kampot Province, the Prek Kompong Saom Bay Delta and Kep municipal waters. The meadows are highly productive, but few animals feed directly on the grasses. Those that do tend to be vertebrates such as sea turtles, dabbling ducks and geese.cite webhttps://php.radford.edu/~swoodwar/biomes/?page_idSeagrass meadows - Biomes of the WorldDepartment of Geospatial Science Radford UniversityJune 7, 2015cite webhttp://www.worldfishcenter.org/Pubs/CambodiaProceedings/pdf/CambodiaProceedings-02.pdfBiodiversity of Cambodia’s WetlandsWorldFish CenterMay 26, 2015cite webhttps://www.mangrovesforthefuture.org/countries/members/cambodia/Cambodia - Mangroves for the FutureMangroves for the FutureMay 26, 2015

"With their roots deep in mud, jagged and gnarled mangrove trees are able to grow in the brackish wetlands between land and sea where other plant life cannot survive. The trees offer refuge and nursery grounds for fish, crabs, shrimp, and mollusks. They are nesting - and migratory sites for hundreds of bird species. They also provide homes for monkeys, lizards, sea turtles, and many other animals as well as countless insects. "

"Until relatively recently, the mangroves of Koh Kong, Cambodia have remained relatively intact. This is partly because of the regions location it is an isolated, inaccessible place and because decades of war and conflict perversely protected the forests from over-exploitation. Local people, however, tended to use the forest's sustainability, for food, fuel, medicine, building materials, and other basic needs. "
article.heading: Fauna
article.paragraph: Cambodia is home to a wide array of wildlife. There are 212mammalspecies, 536birdspecies, 176reptilespecies (including 89 subspecies), 850 freshwaterfishspecies (Tonl SapLake area), and 435 marine fish species. Many of the country's species are recognized by theIUCNor World Conservation Union as threatened, endangered, or critically endangered due toDeforestation in Cambodiadeforestationand habitat destruction,poaching, illegalwildlife trade, farming, fishing, and unauthorized forestry concessions. Intensive poaching may have already driven Cambodia's national animal, theKouprey, to extinction. Wild tigers, Eld's deer, wild water buffaloes and hog deer are at critically low numbers.cite webhttp://www.fauna-flora.org/explore/cambodia/CambodiaFauna & Flora International (FFI)May 26, 2015cite webhttp://www.fauna-flora.org/news/remote-wildlife-eden-uncovered-in-cambodia/Remote wildlife Eden uncovered in CambodiaFauna & Flora International (FFI)May 26, 2015cite webhttp://www.reptile-database.orgReptilesReptile DatabaseJanuary 15, 1999May 20, 2015

article.heading: Land use
article.paragraph: Cambodia, Laos and Vietnam have experienced major changes in land use and land cover over the last two decades. article.heading: Regional divisions
article.paragraph: Cambodia's boundaries were for the most part based upon those recognized byFranceand by neighboring countries during theFrench Protectorate of Cambodiacolonial period. The 800-kilometer boundary with Thailand runs along thedrainage dividewatershedof the Dangrek Mountains, although only in its northern sector. The 541-kilometer border with Laos and the 1,228-kilometer border with Vietnam result from French administrative decisions and do not follow major natural features. Border disputes have broken out in the past and do persist between Cambodia and Thailand as well as between Cambodia and Vietnam.cite webhttps://www.dur.ac.uk/resources/ibru/publications/full/bsb5-2_amer.pdf?originBorder Conflicts between Cambodia and VietnamDurham UniversityMay 16, 2015cite webhttp://www.eastasiaforum.org/2012/01/27/thai-cambodian-conflict-rooted-in-history/Thai–Cambodian conflict rooted in historyEast Asia ForumJanuary 27, 2012May 16, 2015cite webhttp://www.cambodianlifestory.com/thailand-cambodia-a-love-hate-relationships/Thailand-Cambodia " A love-hate relationships"Cambodian Life StoryJanuary 23, 2013June 6, 2015cite webhttp://thediplomat.com/2014/06/cambodias-impossible-dream-koh-tral/ Cambodia’s Impossible Dream: Koh TralThe DiplomatJune 17, 2014June 6, 2015
